item.title: VMware ESXi- Notes, Procedures & Best Practices
item.description:
VMware ESXi is a bare-metal hypervisor that installs directly on server hardware and enables you to run multiple virtual machines (VMs) on a single physical host.

Key Concepts

Term Definition
Hypervisor Software layer that enables virtualization. ESXi is a Type-1 hypervisor.
VMkernel The core OS of ESXi that manages CPU, memory, storage, and networking for VMs.
VMFS VMware File System used for storing VM files.
vSphere Client GUI/HTML5 interface for managing ESXi hosts and vCenter.
vCenter Server Central management platform for multiple ESXi hosts.
vMotion Live migration of VMs between ESXi hosts with no downtime.
HA (High Availability) Automatic restart of VMs on other hosts if a host fails.
DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler) Balances workloads across hosts automatically.
vSAN Software-defined storage that pools local storage across hosts.

Key Features

  • Bare-metal installation
  • Efficient resource management
  • Advanced networking
  • Storage virtualization
  • Security and isolation
  • Enterprise-grade availability features

Benefits

  • High efficiency & performance
  • Scalability
  • Centralized management
  • Strong security posture
  • Broad ecosystem and vendor support

Installation & Configuration (Virtual Environment)

Requirements

  • ESXi ISO

item.title: VMware NSX - Notes, Procedures & Best Practices
item.description:
VMware NSX is a software-defined networking (SDN) platform that virtualizes network functions and security services, enabling network automation, micro-segmentation, and scalable network operations inside virtualized environments.

Core Value

  • Network abstraction: decouples network services from physical hardware
  • Consistent security: micro-segmentation and policy-driven security
  • Automation & agility: integrate networking into CI/CD workflows
  • Operational efficiency: reduce time to deploy networks from days to minutes

NSX Components (High Level)

Component Role
NSX Manager Central control plane and API endpoint
NSX Controllers Control plane (distributed routing, etc.) (NSX-T handles this differently)
NSX Edge North-South routing, load balancing, VPN, NAT
NSX Distributed Firewall (DFW) Micro-segmentation security engine
NSX Data Plane (VIB/VXLAN) Packet forwarding and overlay encapsulation

NSX Editions

  • NSX Data Center (traditional)
  • NSX-T Data Center (multi-hypervisor, Kubernetes, public cloud integration)
  • NSX Advanced Threat Prevention / NSX Intelligence (analytics + threat detection)

NSX Architecture Overview

NSX-T (Modern Standard)

NSX-T is the modern standard for NSX deployments.
